Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 02:04AM - edited Mar 20, 2014 02:09AM by Danishgirl66 Have any of you read Anti cancer, A New Way of Life?  It's written by an MD who discovered his own brain cancer.  He followed conventional treatment but learned all he could about scientific experiments and how other cultures lived.  He did exactly what MusicLover enumerated.  I thought it a very interesting, readable book.  He never said it was a cure but felt his life was much better and also prolonged because of the changes he made.  Who knows? Janice, I like your diet. MusicLover, I'm not sure about intuition or taking supplements is a good idea.

Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2016 02:31AM Danishgirl66 wrote: I was started on Halaven and Faslodex about 1 1/2 years ago. My TM's seem to be a pretty good indication of what is going on with the ILC in my abdomen. After about two months my TM's started going down and four months after that were in the normal range. A CT showed no evidence of disease. Yay! NED! MO stopped the Halaven. Then about 5 months later the TM's started going up again. The Halaven worked before so why not use it again. TM's went down again and I've been off Halaven since late October. CT in November showed something suspicious in thoracic and lumbar spine. PET showed NED. I asked my MO how he could be sure since ILC can be very hard to diagnose from scans. He said it showed very clearly 1 1/2 years ago. I'd love to say I feel great, but I still have some abdominal pain. Lots of pain from neuropathy and generally achy but no problem getting around. Both times I lost about 1/2 hair on Halaven, but it grew back in the six months off and is growing back again. I'm still feeling a lot of fatigue but not as much as when I'm on Halaven. Right now I'm on Faslodex and Aromasin but I'm pretty sure I will be back on Halaven when my TM's start to go up. I also take Protonix for acid reflux and Ursodiol for a "sandy gallbladder" I hope this was of help to somebody and that we all can find that magic that will give us a little more time.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Neither Faslodex nor Halaven have changed my neuropathy. My hair is getting very thin on the Halaven, however. (Sigh)

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2014 12:37AM Danishgirl66 wrote: Hi Barb,  I take Celebrex for joint and muscle pain, but it really seemed to stop the aching in my hands at night that would wake me up.  I don't know if it is from peripheral neuropathy.  I don't think I have arthritis.   Does anyone take Claritin for peripheral neuropathy?   One of my chemo nurses suggested it, but I can't remember if it was just to be taken on chemo days. I'm taking Miralax every day, but have no idea if I need it from Halaven, Faslodex, rads or mets in my abdomen.  When I was taking A/A, I was having diarrhea.

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2014 08:52PM Danishgirl66 wrote: Dancingveggie,  Do you  think it could be fluid retention?  If you are not eating much and gaining weight,  that could be the problem.  I'm always tired and occasionally have a low grade fever.  I lost 30 lbs on A/A, but it didn't work for me and was very unpleasant.  I'm starting on my 3ed round. I'm on Halaven, Faslodex, Aromasin and just finished rads for skin mets, so it hard to tell which SE comes from where.  I'm a little dizzy at times, constipated, nausea occasionally and a headache most of the time, but it's tolerable most of the time.  MaryAnne

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2014 04:54PM Danishgirl66 wrote: Hi Claire,  How did you first infusion of Halaven go?  I've been on it since June .  My only SE's are fatigue and I'velost about 2/3's of my hair.  I'm also on once monthly injectable Faslodex and daily oral Aromasin.  My tumor markers have come down to normal. The only other med I've bee on since diagnosed with mets has been oral Afinitor.  It made me have abdominal cramping and mush worse fatigue.  I'm a lot happier with Halaven and Faslodex.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 04:03AM Danishgirl66 wrote: I don't mind the word "journey."  I see it as either traveling or your path in life, sometimes good and sometimes traumatic.  Cancer of course is quite traumatic.  I don't really like the words  "fighting" or "battling" cancer, because like several of you have said I didn't choose to have it.  I am being treated for it by the best medicine I can find, very appreciative of my husbands great medical plan and doing everything I can to be healthy and active.  I guess I'm a "survivor" until I am not a survivor.  The survivor part is what makes me really sad.
